The party are very kind and courteous, but the raid they make upon bottles of champagne and wines is to me a marvel. The lady takes her glass with as much ease as the gentleman. I have been courteously invited to join them but frankly told them I never in my life tasted the article and had no need for anything of the kind. They opened their eyes with 


                                    -99- 

astonishment. . . . I treat the different parties with my precious fruit and they try hard to make some exchange but fail. . . . They feel disturbed to think they are in my debt.--Letter 22, 1883, pp. 1, 2. ("To Dear Children," August 15, 1883.)
